Lawyers for Shukri Walker say she will give evidence as part of the sexual abuse civil case brought against the Duke of York in the US. Attorney Lisa Bloom said: “She is willing to do the deposition Virginia Giuffre’s team is seeking. “I am proud to represent Shukri Walker, who has bravely stepped forward as a witness and encourages others who may have information to do so as well.” Walker has previously told the FBI she definitively remembered seeing Andrew in March  inside London’s Tramp nightclub. title: extraordinary story britains anne frank
story: Extraordinary story of Britains Anne Frank hidden behind trap doors from Nazis in UKPhyliss Emily Le Breton and her husband John kept Tom hidden away behind trap doors after he managed to flee his German captors during the Nazi regimeTom was the Ukrainian prisoner of war whom the Le Bretons housed and fed Image: Carolyn Horn   SWNSByAdam AspinallNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  A family has revealed the extraordinary story of aposBritainaposs Anne Frank apos who hid from the Nazis in their home - and even kept a diary.Phyliss Emily Le Breton and her husband John kept aposTomapos hidden away behind trap doors after he managed to flee his German captors. Tom - real name Bokejon Akram - was a Russian soldier and school teacher taken as a POW by the Third Reich. They took him to the occupied Channel Island of Jersey as a slave but he managed to escape and was taken in by Phyliss and John. They risked their lives by hiding him in their house where he had trap door escape routes.Have your say on this story in the comment section He told their five young kids fairy stories and even kept a diary - just like the teenage Anne Frank in Amsterdam. The family called him aposTomapos and taught him English – partly by reading the Bible with him. He survived with them for three years and was repatriated to the Ukraine in  by the British. They lost touch after the war and the familyaposs story has now emerged as officials at Jersey Heritage try to discover more about him. Phyliss and Emilyaposs grand-daughter Carolyn Horn, , said she was immensely proud of what her family risked to save Tomaposs le. Carolyn, who lives in Cyprus with her husband and three children, said: He became a member of the family. aposaposMy aunt said she called him her favourite uncle, as that was how he was known - Uncle Tom. My grandmother used to talk about Tom all the time. It just shows what kind people they were. It makes me proud.  It was a time of crisis and they had German soldiers walking in whenever. aposaposThey still risked their own lives, and the lives of their children, to help someone who they didnapost even know and let live in their house as a member of their family. There was a little door under the staircase in the house with a trap door behind it - that is how Tom could get from one side of the house to the other.aposapos Phyliss and John are reported to have said: We trusted this man, he was the sort of man we could trust. The children loved him and, when he could understand some English, he used to read them fairy stories. Tomaposs journey began in July  when the young Ukrainian soldier and unmarried school teacher defended his country against German attack. During a two hour period , of his colleagues died and Tom alongside many other Ukrainians became a PoW. The German soldiers collected thousands of people and used them as slave labourers to quarry stone and build coastal defences.  Tom then found himself with , others taken to St Malo in Jersey in July . He was put into hard labour but managed to run away and was found in St Mary - by Phyliss, John, and their four very young children. They were nervous and so renamed Bokejon as Tom to reduce the risk of discoverytheir kids said anything.  Tom slept in in the stables behind a trap door, in a car hidden behind bales of straw and in a shed in case the Germans called. Phylissaposs daughter Dulcie, now in her s, remembers him reading fairy stories to the children and playing with them. Dulcie, who was four when the Occupation began, remembers Tom like a favourite uncle. In May , before repatriation to the Ukraine by British forces, Tom promised to keep in contact.  Three letters arrived in June  from Guernsey where Tom was last known to be - but then nothing. Years later John was one of  Jersey men and women awarded a gold watch by the Soviet government for their courage in helping to shelter Russian and Ukrainian escapees. Historians at Jersey Heritage have now issued a plea for anyone to come forward with more information about him. Chris Addy, sites curator, said they were surprised how much they had been able to find out about them.He said: It’s always a bit of a guess. You never know what stories are going to come out after  years.It’s always fascinating to hear a new piece of information or research, and add it to the stories that we tell each year to remind people about this signicant part of the Island’s history.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Uncle TomAnne FrankEducationSoldiersNazis" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Healthy man, , who came back from dead after Covid battle issues vaccine pleaJames, , from Walsall, West Midlands, was put into an induced coma for  days while battling Covid and now struggles to walk, needing carers to help himJames has pleaded with those still reluctant to get the Covid vaccine Image: Walsall Healthcare NHS TrustByOprah FlashRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Jan | comments A Covid survivor who came back from the dead while fighting the virus has pleaded with naysayers to get the vaccine. James, , from Walsall, West Midlands, believes he contracted coronavirus during a night out in Birmingham and was left in a -day coma as a result of the virus. The fitness fanatic suffered headaches, loss of appetite and light-headedness before recording a positive lateral flow test. His condition quickly deteriorated, reports Birmingham Live. “I was sweating and I couldn’t stand up properly,” said James. “As I was going home my throat was tight and I was struggling to breathe, so I called .” At Walsall Manor Hospital, James was told there was a long wait for admission and decided to go home before ing the next morning.  Two more trips to AE followed after James suffered hallucinations. He was still feeling unwell and light-headed, and the second time, he passed out. James added: “I was having nightmares, and the next thing I knew, I was in ICU. “They told me I had a lack of oxygen to the brain and at one stage I was told I had died and they had to resuscitate me. He was placed in an induced coma for  days and spent more than a month in hospital before eventually getting on the road to recovery. But then he was dealt another Covid-related blow. Recalling the horrying experience, he said: “A doctor asked, ‘can you walk ’ So I tried but I collapsed like a newborn donkey. “I really struggled to talk too because I was so out of breath.”  After  days in the hospital, he has become so weak that he now needs carers to support his everyday needs. Reflecting on being so scared at what happened to him, he had no hesitation in getting the vaccine after also being encouraged to do so by family members.“I am fit, healthy and as fit as a fiddle and I caught Covid- with no underlying health problems whatsoever,” he said.“Having Covid- is no joke and it’s not going anywhere. The reason I had the vaccine was to lessen my anxiety because I’ve just been in ICU and I really don’t want to go into hospital again. “Anyone who doesn’t have the vaccine is an idiot. Having some help to protect you is better than having no help –you just rely on your body to fight it, it’s not enough.” James now encourages friends to follow suit. “Some of my mates who know my situation now take it more seriously and have now been vaccinated,” he added. “I text them saying ‘make sure you do’. I was lucky – I came out of it the other side. Normally I am someone who thinks they can just sleep these things off but I am a transformed person and I’m glad I listened to my family. “As someone from the Afro-Caribbean community, I would urge everyone to forget any stubbornness about it because that won’t keep you alive.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HospitalsFitnessCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Introvert gamer spent over a month setting up elaborate gaming stunt to proposeJerome Javillonar left his girlfriend stunned after he created a special version of their favourite game Genshin Impact - creating special levels and mazes Ronica Cabansag had to completeRonica shows her engagement ring after complete levels to reveal hidden messages leading to a proposal in her favourite computer game Image: Ronica Cabansag FacebookByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments An introvert gamer spent more than a month setting up an elaborate gaming stunt to propose to his girlfriend. Jerome Javillonar left his girlfriend Ronica Cabansag in absolute shock when he created a special version of their favourite game Genshin Impact - creating special levels and mazes she had to complete.Ronica described her boyfriend, now fiance, as an extreme introvert - and said she was shocked by the proposal because Jerome wasnapost usually into romantic stuff.Speaking about the moment he asked her to marry him, Ronica said she was asked to go to his home out of the blue, reports the Daily Star. She said she had the feeling something was going on, but added: My mind wouldn’t accept it because I know he’s not into romantic stuff.  “When I opened his bedroom door, I saw lights and balloons. I got mixed emotions. joined by husband William for their first royal outing of the year to hear of the challenges of those who turned their lives around after growing up in chaotic homes.Kateaposs stylish budget look included a Jigsaw coat  subtle earrings which cost just £.Kate, who last year set up her Centre for Early Childhood, and Wills spoke with charity bosses at the Foundling Museum who discussed homelessness, mental health impact and helping young people in care who fail or slip through the cracks.The museum which tells the history of the Foundling Hospital, the UKaposs first childrenaposs charity founded in , as a home for children whose mothers couldn’t keep or care for them.  Taking their seats, Kate, , who arrived in a smart navy coat and a black polo neck for the engagement in central London, asked the experts: From your experience what makes the dference between a young person succeeding after leaving foster care and when they do not. They heard about challenges for young people when they regularly move home and are sometimes exploited by the criminal world. William added: If you keep moving a child around when they are an adult their relationships are so short and shallow. Kate said she was concerned that without providing stable homes for children they risk being moved around and having to tell their story again and again. Will said: That may become emotionally exhausting to tell the story again and again. Weaposve had that in the mental health side of things, people end up on the street, go through hoops and hurdles, tell so many people in authority and nothing changes. You have to get to them a lot earlier so they donapost have to keep doing this. Later as they left the event William, , could not avoid the drama of his own family as a TV crew asked the Duke do you support Prince Andrew  as the couple left the museum. The Duke leaned closer to hear but then walked past without commenting. Part of their engagement, handpicked by the couple to be their first event of the year, saw them discuss the worry about the consistency in care:  Olympic hero runner Kris Akabusi, poet Lemn Sissay, and Allan Jenkins, editor of Observer Food Monthly, told the Duke and Duchess their experiences of growing up in care. Akabusi said: I enjoyed the stability. It was a saviour for me. He said leaving care aged -years-old was very traumatic. Kate replied: You are petried leaving for independence. She asked the m hurdlerit had affected his relationships. Kris, with his distinctive laugh, replied: Yes, but I am a loner. He added: Now aged  there is no stigma attached when I say I was brought up in care but there was a stigma when I was . Women who had previously been in care then joined the couple in an aposice-breakerapos armed with three-foot long pencils. They drew on a canvas what they could see in front of them without looking down at the floor. Kate - who scored a master of arts degree in art history at St Andrews University - laughed out as she struggled with the artwork which had the look of a vast doodle when it was finished. Duke laughed and said: I enjoyed it. The kids would really enjoy that. Viewing their masterpiece, he added: Thataposs beautul. Athlete Kris Akabusi said afterwards: It is great to have so many vital resources for young people. As a young person in care, to know people at the top are interested in your story and growth as an adult is very encouraging. Hopefully they are not forgotten. Young people who were in care are over-represented in gangs, sex industry and crime, I hope society has not forgotten them as these children are in care throigh no fault of their ownnso it is great to have this infrastructure. The Foundling Museum tells the history of the Foundling Hospital, the UK’s first children’s charity. It was founded in  as a home for children whose mothers couldn’t keep or care for them. The Museum delivers training, mentorship programmes and creative projects, led and developed by contemporary artists, writers and musicians, to continue to use creative action to transform and improve the lives of care-experienced young people. It helps around  adults who grew up in care every year. The Tracing Our Tales is described as a unique programme which has been developed to equip care-experienced young adults from London boroughs with the skills to devise and deliver workshops at the Museum for family groups. The programme provides paid employment and valuable le skills, including public speaking, critical and creative thinking, and people management, as well as skills in art and creative expression. news uk-news man-says-delivery-driver-yelled-"DoorDash delivery woman appears to say youre so fat after delivering foodByMirror:,  Jan | commentsA man claims that his delivery driver called out “you’re so fat” as she dropped his takeaway at the front door have ided opinion, after he shared footage of the incident on TikTok.TikToker Jay Manubi@jaymanubi posted the clip, taken from a security camera overlooking his front porch, which shows a DoorDash delivery driver calling something out after leaving his food at the door.He is claiming the woman called out “you’re so fat” before she walked back to her vehicle, but his interpretation of what was said, has caused heated debate from viewers. Manubi’s overlay text on the video, reading “DoorDash food delivery girl is not getting a tip after THAT comment!!” makes it clear that he believes the delivery driver called out a rude comment, along with the TikTok caption: “I may have ordered a little too much but that comment was a little overboard” and the hashtag “youresofat”. However, the TikTok has since received .m views, , likes, along with thousands of comments - many of which are from people who believe all is not what it seems. Some claims in the comments section are from people who believe Manubi misheard the delivery and that she was saying something  entirely. One person wrote: “I heard ‘Your foods up.’” Another person said: “She said ‘It’s DoorDash…’ Karen.” Someone  replied: “Bro she said ‘foods outside.’ “She definitely didn’t say that, you can tell just from the way she says it that she was just telling you the food was outside,” a fourth person replied. Other more cynically-minded TikTokers accused Manubi of using the misinterpretation as an excuse to not pay the driver a tip.  “She said ‘It’s DoorDash’ you just want to be cheap,” one person said. While some viewers were against Manubi, others backed him and his claims. One person said: “I can definitely hear the pronounced F at the end for fat. There’s no way she said DoorDash or anything . It doesn’t even sound similar.” “It’s pretty clear, she said it,” another person wrote. Someone  added: “LMAO BRO SHE LITERALLY SAID IT ARE U GUYS DEAF.” A portion of viewers sat on the fence, or were simply confused. “What did she say ” one asked. Another person wrote: “At first I heard ‘ur foods up’ but I watched it again and heard “ur so fat”. Reading the comments, it appears there is no conclusive answer. news uk-news professor-shares--omicron-covid-"Omicron: The first eight symptoms to look out forByHarry Thompson:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsOmicron is is still everywhere and despite very promising signs among the numbers of new cases in the UK, tens of thousands of people continue to pick up the virus every day. The announcement that Plan B measures, which mandated people wearing masks and working from home where possible, will be lted on January  comes as welcome news to many.Because of the still-high numbers, the likelihood of fewer masks, and public places and transport getting a little busier in the coming weeks, it is important to know what to look out for.It is also important for the millions who have been vaccinated to be familiar with Covid symptoms and be able to recognise how they may dfer from symptoms among the unvaccinated. An array of studies has found that Omicron is, on the whole, a milder iant of the virus, with the first official UK report finding that it is between  and % less likely to cause hospitalisation than Delta.Despite this, getting your booster jab remains the best way to protect yourself and those around you from the virus. What symptoms should people look out forthey are vaccinated   Although its findings are not peer-reviewed, the ZOE Covid app study is a useful indicator that pools together the symptoms experienced by people who have tested positive for the virus.Data collected by it has found there are nine symptoms that keep cropping up. Professor Tim Spector, who is one of the key figures behind the project told newsGP : The  million reports submitted via the study’s app have shown that as the virus has evolved, so too have the symptoms it causes. Back in , it quickly became clear that the original and Alpha versions of the coronavirus caused three very common symptoms – cough, fever and loss of smell – as well as at least  others. When Delta appeared, we then noticed a sht in the most frequently reported symptoms. Cold-like symptoms – including a runny nose, sore throat and persistent sneezing – became more common, along with a headache and cough, particularly in people who had been vaccinated. He added: It’s causing symptoms that are much more like a regular cold, particularly in people who’ve been vaccinated, and fewer general systemic symptoms, such as nausea, muscle pains, diarrhoea and skin rashes. This means the nine common symptoms among the vaccinated according to respondents who have added their data to the ZOE Covid app are:Runny noseSore throatSneezing Headache Cough Nausea Muscle painsDiarrhoeaSkin rashThese are of course not necessarily the only things to keep an eye out for but are handy to know aboutyou find yourself developing any of these symptoms. title: really odd new check out
story: Really odd new check-out free Aldi with  smart cameras baffles shoppersGerman supermarket chain Aldi has entered the burgeoning checkout-free shopping race, launching its first Shop  Go store in Greenwich, southeast London, on Monday morningGreenwich -year-old Bill had been waiting for the shop to open Image: Tim MerryByMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsI have been waiting for this for years, explains Bill, an -year-old man grasping a bag full of avocados and crème fraiche. I absolutely hate standing at check-outs.Bill is one of a flock of people who headed to Greenwich to try out Aldi Shop  Go, the budget supermarketaposs first cashless store, on its second day of opening.After a dficult start to his shop involving five dferent members of staff valiantly trying to download an app onto his phone, Bill got through the automatic gates and into the fruit and veg aisle. The retired BT worker appeared through the exit ten minutes later an advocate of the new system. I will definitely be coming back, he smiled. If Aldi can convert more octogenarians like Bill to the cashless shopping cause, then the German company is probably onto a winner. When it opened its flagship south London shop on Monday Aldi was following in the footsteps of Amazon Fresh.  The American retail giant stripped away much of the inbuilt faff of food shopping by ditching human and automated tills when it launched in London last year. Like its rival, Aldi asks shoppers to download and enter their card details into an app, which is then sent a rundown of how much theyaposve stuffed into their trolleys. Unlike Amazon Fresh - which monitors products via pressure pads on shelves - Aldi tracks who has grabbed what with a huge rig of  cameras that hangs from the ceiling. The storeaposs Articial Intelligence computer system then denotes each person a stick figure, so as not to log any identying characteristics and watches as the virtual you select items.  Aldi insists that the ultra-high-tech surveillance model means shoppers can pick up a product, place it in their bag and then put it back on a shelf without being charged. I put this claim to the test during my visit by selecting and then unselecting pineapples, bananas and melons multiple times while turning small circles with my wheelie-cart. Somehow the omniscient grocery gods knew only to add a banana to the receipt that dropped onto my phone half an hour later. Shoppers leaving the store agreed that the smart system sped up the supermarket experience considerably. Xanthe Williams, who lives in Greenwich and runs Fourth Day PR, said the shop had been fun and that she would come back.  Yasmine Aysha, a full-time mum-of-two from the area, managed to pile her buggy high with items in just fteen minutes - far quicker than her usual round. Like mum Kerry Palmer, from Greenwich, they also agreed that the experience would take a bit of getting used to. It was proper weird, she said.How do they know what you are picking up  Itaposs just really odd. It feels like you are shoplting without shoplting. Another small thrill that Aldi Shop  Go offers is the chance to be aged by its computer system. As soon as shoppers pick up an age-restricted product, such as a beer, paracetamol or four-pack of energy drinks, the AI machine triggers the age verication system. You must then show a staff member your ID or open the app and look deep into the camera. If the unforgiving binary eye that looks back decides you look over-, youaposre good to go. If youaposre lucky enough to look younger, staff will come and manually approve the purchase. It can only be a matter of time before a teenager with a head full of talcum powder, horn-rimmed glasses and a brown mackintosh attempts to game the system. When the novelty of the experience wears off, as one suspects it will after a few shops and failed attempts to trick the computer, it will be interesting to see how Aldi Shop  Go measures up to a typical supermarket.  For many people, a trip to the shops is a social activity that culminates in a chat with a cashier. Although there were many staff on hand to help customers navigate the new app, it has to be assumed that the final product will be much more streamlined. Some are wary of the impact this could have on the high street. Dr Jackie Mulligan, founder of local shopping  ShopAppy, warned: “Checkout-free stores are sterilising the high-street experience. Yes, they bring some advantages in terms of time savings, but they come at the cost of basic human interaction. “Technology is the future but people need to play a part in it, too. If Covid has taught us anything, it is the importance of social interaction. words on why Boris Johnson was naughty was today hailed as the next Prime Minister as she appeared on TV to declare he needs to leave.Five-year-old Layla Somani went viral last week with her astute explanation of the nationaposs fury over the Toriesapos lockdown parties in Downing Street, which she shared with her grandparents Kanti Somani, , and Kusun Somani, .The young girl didnapost hold back when she told them Mr Johnson is not a prime minister anymore, heaposs a bad prime minister. Layla also confirmed she stuck to the rules herself during lockdown, and her fourth birthday party was held on Zoom. Sarah-Jane then askedLayla forgave the PM for the parties. However, when asked what should happen to Mr Johnson, little Layla didnapost mince her words when she declared: I think he should leave because he has been naughty. Parents Devina Somani, , and Nick Somani, , filmed the cutthroat monologue and were sat beside her today as she gave her blistering verdict. Her comments have left many online hailing her as the next PM. One wrote: Layla for Prime Minsiter! She doesnapost need luck, she knows the rules. Another wrote: Fantastic! A third chimed in: May God bless her, she speaks more sense than the grown-up politicians especially our PM.In last weekaposs video, which has been viewed thousands of times, Layla told her doting grandparents:Boris Johnson told everyone to stay at home, but in lockdown he just went down to a party, in the lockdown. She continued: Now he canapost be prime minister anymore and he canapost go back to his prime minister home, so heaposs not prime minister anymore. So, someone  is being prime minister and there will be a good prime minister, but Boris Johnson is not a prime minister anymore, heaposs a bad prime minister.Mr Johnson may be forgiven by Layla, but he still faces calls to quit after continuing allegations of rule-breaking parties in No and further accusations he has lied to Parliament.  Yesterday, he claimed nobody told me that a boozy lockdown bash in the Downing Street garden broke Covid rules. He broke cover for the first time in days to insist that he hadnapost lied to Parliament about the event in May , which he has admitted attending for  minutes. news uk-news tonga-volcano-triggers-mystery-waves-"In pictures: England v TongaByAntony Thrower:,  Jan | comments Scientists have been baffled by mysterious ripples in the Earth’s atmosphere, seemingly triggered by the massive eruption of the underwater Tongan volcano. Satellite data shows unusual atmospheric gravity waves since Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha’apai’s eruption on Saturday which triggered massive ft tsunamis, devastating the island nation. The massive blast also created unusual gravity waves stretching around , kilometres, which have never been seen before, reports Nature. The data was collected by the Atmospheric Infrared Sounderon board a Nasa satellite orbiting the planet. Lars Hoffmann, an atmospheric scientist at the Jülich Supercomputing Centre in Germany, said: “It’s really unique. We have never seen anything like this in the data before.What do you make of the mystery ripples  Have your say in the comment section “This instrument has been operating for something like  years now and we have never seen such nice concentric wave patterns.” The pictures show dozens of concentric circles in the atmosphere which possibly cross the planet several times. Scott Osprey, from the University of Oxford, believes the eruption’s speed could possibly have caused the mystery waves.  One of the possible effects of the waves is the reversal of wind direction which could have an impact in Europe. He added: “This event seems to have been over in minutes, but it was explosive and it’s that impulse that is likely to kick off some strong gravity waves. “We’ll be looking very carefully at how that evolves.”  Hundreds of homes in Tongaaposs smaller outer islands are feared to have been destroyed in the tsunami, with at least three dead. Information on the scale of devastation has come mostly from reconnaissance aircraft as the nation’s airport is smothered by ash and communications have been hampered. Teams from The Red Cross say drinking water has been polluted by salt water from the tsunami and volcanic ash. Hunga-Tonga-Hunga-Haaposapai has erupted regularly over the past few decades but the impact of Saturdayaposs blast was felt as far away as Japan and the United States. The eruption was also detected by volunteer meteorologists in Hastings, East Sussex. story: Woman turned le around after chance encounter with cruel stranger on holidayRochelle Hardy was on her first big holiday with her boyfriend Sam to Budapest in  when a group of men made a comment that she was a fat c*** not realising she spoke EnglishAt her heaviest, Rochelle was a size  and weighed nearly  stone Image: FOCUS FEATURESByAnn CusackAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A woman has told of how she turned her le around and lost a six-and-a-half stone after a cruel comment on holiday left her devastated.Rochelle Hardy was on her first big holiday to Budapest in  with her new boyfriend Sam when a strangeraposs comment changed everything. At the time Rochelle was a size  and severely overweight, weighing nearly  stone. Rochelle says: “Actually, those blokes on holiday did me a favour because it was the trigger I needed to turn my le around.” Rochelle grew up in Spain, with English parents, and said she used to get teased at school about her weight. Have you got an inspiring weight loss story  Email webnews@mirror She says: “I went to school in Spain, and the kids called me ‘La Gorda’ which means ‘the fat one.’ My dad would give me spending money every day on the way to school I would pop into the sweet shop with my two euros, filling my bag with sweets. I have a photo of me as a teenager in a bikini, with my hands over my stomach because I am so self-conscious. I wasn’t even hugely overweight at that point, but I hated my body. “My confidence was low, but I didn’t let people know about it. I was pretty tough on the outside.” Rochelle moved back to the UK when she was  and met her current partner, Sam, , in Liverpool. She says: “It sounds like a cliché, but I piled on weight after I met Sam. We were very comfortable, and we ate loads of takeaways and we loved buying pick and mix sweets. Sam was very skinny, but he loved me how I was and paid me lots of compliments.” Rochelle soon weighed -stone and nine pounds and was a dress size . Being just five feet and five inches tall, she was classed as obese. Rochelle and Sam went on their first holiday together to Budapest in , where a group of men made the cruel comment. She says: “There was a group of English blokes nearby and one said: ‘Look at that fat c*** and they all laughed. Obviously, they didn’t know that I was English, but that didn’t excuse it. “I ran into a nearby toilet block and sobbed. “The rest of the holiday was totally miserable for me, and I knew things had to change. That was the turning point.”  When she got back to the UK, Rochelle joined a gym and began eating low-calorie foods - and she lost more than a stone.By October , she joined a Liverpool Slimming World group with a friend and quickly began to lose weight.Rochelle has managed to lose an amazing six and a half stones and she now weighs nine stones and  pounds. Rochelle says she now exercises regularly and eats healthily. Rochelle says: I can happily walk into a room now and not feel like everyone is looking at me, itaposs changed my le. Iaposm not hiding myself away anymore. “That comment in Budapest really upset me but actually they did me a huge favour. That was the turning point for me. story: Dad wished hed checked order after daughter plays ultimate McDonalds prankA dad was left in hysterics when he realised that his daughter had made a few major modications to the Mcdonalds Big Mac he was ordering from the JustEat appKelsie and Gaz Image: Jam Press Heather LeverByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan | commentsA little girl left her dad in hysterics after she played the ultimate McDonaldaposs prank on him. Kelsie, , from Bolton, was entrusted by her dad Gaz Grfin to place her standard Big Mac order through the JustEat app. But while Gaz, , was tidying the bedroom upstairs, Ky saw an opportunity to play a prank on him. She removed the burgeraposs signature two beef patties, along with pickles, shredded lettuce, onion, sesame bun and the iconic Big Mac sauce. She then opted to go large on the meal and order extra Big Mac sauce. When the £. meal turned up at the door  minutes later, the prankster raced upstairs to hand her dad the box with just a slice of cheese inside. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. I found it funny. It was my own fault for not checking it over first, Gaz said. With all those options she obviously got a bit too giddy. Iaposm just surprised that no one rang to check thataposs what we wanted. Kelsie and her younger sister Portia, eight, had been staying at their dadaposs house at the weekend when they were askedthey wanted a takeaway for dinner. Gaz added: She came running upstairs shouting daddy, look at this.  I was so confused when she showed me the Big Mac box, so I checked over the order and realised what sheaposd done. I wasnapost too worried about the waste of money, I just found it amusing that sheaposd paid to go large too as well as extra sauce, after asking for no sauce. I did order her another, that I did myself this time! It was good of JustEat to refund us for it. When they ed home to their mum Heatheraposs house the next day, Kelsie retold her antics. Heather, a communications and marketing manager, added: When Gaz dropped the girls off home Sunday night, itaposs a common theme that I ask them what theyaposve eaten with him so I donapost repeat the same meals. I couldnapost help but laugh when asking Kelsie what sheaposd ordered from Mcdonaldaposs on the Saturday. God knows what the person at McDonaldaposs thought when they received the order.Heather uploaded photos of the meal onto Facebook, where it has racked up , likes so far.The post read: If you’re going to let your children add their own order on just eat, always check it before submitting it. My -year-old’s dad learnt this the hard way. Facebook users were quick to see the funny side, with one writing: I can’t believe they would actually only send a piece of cheese tho they must have a right laugh sometimes [sic] Another added: They must’ve had a right laugh putting that together. What’s with the no sauce then extra sauce, wrote a third bemused user. Another said that, despite the lack of ingredients, the post still made them hungry, commenting: This made me laugh, want a Big Mac now though. I’m vegetarian and love cheese so this is perfect for me but oh no! added someone . Others felt sorry for Gaz, commenting: Most expensive slice of cheese heaposll ever buy. A second Facebooker glaringly pointed out: Expensive cheese slice that. title: what wordle viral word game
story: What is Wordle  Viral word game spreading like wildfire on Twitter to challenge your brainWordle has most definitely taken over the Internet and most of our lives. Here are some clever tips to keep in mind while playing the simple but addictive word gameWordle is the addictive word game taking over TwitterByMalvika PadinTrends Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsEveryone seems to be playing Wordle, the viral puzzle game is a free, easy-to-access brain teaser that has quickly become the most trendy game around the world.The viral game, which can be played from any browser on any device, is simple and addictive, and lets you share your scores online as well. You may have seen these plastered all over the internet. While the game is quite easy to understand and play, it can get frustratingyouaposre only seeing grey squares with each guess you make. So, here are some tips to remember that will help you ace the game thataposs been trending on Twitter.What is Wordle   Wordle is a simple but tricky word puzzle which asks players to solve just one word puzzle per day. The word is always made up of five letters, that is the same for everyone who plays the game, and since thereaposs a new word every day you can make a habit of it and play it daily. The aim of the game is to guess the single word each time you play - you have six attempts to get it right. If you don’t get the word in six tries, you have to wait until the next day to try again with a new word. How does Wordle work   The addictive game uses a colour-coded system to give you a little hint which lets you knowa letter is in the right spot or not, with every guess you make. For example,you guess a word incorrectly, but one of the letters is right and in the correct position, that box turns green. If a letter in a word is correct but not in the right spot in your guess, then the box turns yellow. If none of the letters in your guess is the correct answer, the box turns grey. The game also lets you challenge yourself with a aposhard modeapos, which forces players to use hints given by the game, stopping you from guessing words at random. Since the word is the same for everyone, its quite fun to compare your guesses and scores with that of friends, family or even strangers playing online. Evenyou donapost get the answer right, the game still lets you share your scores online, which means you can have a laugh about the incorrect guesses youaposve made. Wordle Tips Luck goes a long way with Wordle, but some clever tips and tricks that make things a little easier to get started. Remember the following:Though the creator of the game, Josh Wardle is from UK, Wordle is based on American English Letters can, and often do, appear twice in words. Each word will appear only once, because Mr Wardle created the game using words his we recognised Use the same rules as Scrabble, like Qs need Us, and Zs are uncommon.Good starting words on Wordle are: NOTES RESIN TARES SENOROther frequently appearing letters that are good options to use in your second guess includes I,O,T,N and S.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON EntertainmentLatest TrendBoxing DayNew YearPrince HarryRoyal FamilyViralBikinis" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: woman branded inconsiderate after car
story: Woman branded inconsiderate after car headlights wake up sleeping neighboursA woman has shared how she starts her car  minutes before she has to leave for work in the morning to warm it up, but her neighbours really arent happy about itThe woman has been arguing with her neighbours about her morning routineImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Jan | commentsOne of the worst things about heading to work in the middle of winter is getting into a freezing cold car in the morning and waiting what seems like forever for the heating to kick in and warm your fingers up. To combat the cold, one woman on Reddit uses her caraposs auto-startto switch her engine on  minutes before she leaves the house - but her actions have been upsetting her new neighbours. Sharing her story anonymously, the woman - who is from the US - explained the auto-startautomatically switches on her caraposs headlights and said her neighbours have complained that the bright lights wake them up. She said: Iaposve lived in this same apartment building for  years. The apartment owners decided to add on to the parking lot around seven years ago, adding one row of parking between another building and mine. Iaposve been parking on this newer part because I can see my car from my living room sliding glass door. Plus it is within my caraposs auto-start range.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. I have a pretty strict morning routine, and at : during weekdays I autostart my car in the winter to warm it up. I always leave at :, unless there is a lot of snow to clear. But during those  minutes, my lights are on and point at either the apartments across from me or into the living rooms on my complex. The woman said she recently got into a confrontation with her neighbour about her lights after the man fell asleep in his living room and was rudely awoken by the bright beams. The woman agreed to turn her lights off when she parked up for the night so they wouldnapost turn on in the morning - but she forgot to do so and doesnapost think it should be that big of a deal.  She added: Yesterday when I got home from work, the new neighbours below me opened their sliding glass door and told me not to shine my lights into their apartment. I said, aposThataposs your living room, right  Iaposm always gone in  minutes, is it really that big of a deal apos The guy said that he fell asleep in his living room and I woke him up that morning, and he forgot to close his blinds. I apologised and said Iaposd try to remember to turn my lights off before I come home in the evening. Of course, I forgot, but this morning he had his blinds closed.  Am I really the a**hole here  Itaposs only for  minutes and itaposs not like Iaposm shining them directly into his bedroom. Iaposve never had this problem with anyone after living here so long. Commenters on the Reddit post were split, as many agreed that the woman was being inconsiderate by not taking her neighbouraposs needs into account. One person wrote: Itaposs only one second for you to turn your lights off and one second in the morning to turn them back on. It doesnapost matter that itaposs new neighbours. They complained. You can solve it. Iaposm sure you can afford to add one second to your strict morning routine. While another said: It’s pretty inconsiderate of you as a neighbour to shine that much light through their window. It takes minimal effort on your part to keep a neighbourly vibe. But others insisted the woman wasnapost purposefully trying to upset her neighbours, and instead suggested ways she could remember to turn her lights off in the future. Someone said: Stick a Post-it Note on your steering wheel to turn your lights off. Leave it there, so you remember to turn them back on in the morning. As someone  posted: This sounds like it happened one night only and then she said she would try to fix it. Most people don’t accidentally fall asleep in the living room so it’s the only time this guy had a problem. But I agreeit’s hard to remember to use notes to help. What do you think of the womanaposs neighbour dispute  Let us know in the comments below. news world-news hairdresser-shares-horric-lice-infestation-"Hairdresser shows lice infestation in child’s hairByRia NewmanLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan A hairdresser shared a harrowing video of a child who had to have her head shaved because it was infested with lice.Rachel Maroun, , from Sydney, Australia, works as a head lice technician and shares clips of her most severe cases online.Her recent clip went viral on TikTok and led to the little girl being taken away by Child Protective Services . “I could tell the lice were draining more than just her blood, she looked sick and was covered in lice bites over her body, she said. Rachel told how the girl, who she estimates was aged between six and seven, came in with a headscarf on and showed her the infestation which was the worst Rachel had ever seen. The child was later taken to hospital and needed to have her head shaved. “She was very quiet and showed me how the lice were biting down her neck and back, since there was little to no space for them to crawl freely in her hair,” Rachel said. “Immediately when I saw her I knew something was wrong and that this would be the biggest case of lice I’ve had to face. “I’m used to extreme lice infestations but was definitely not prepared for what I saw. “I was told that the child had been dealing with the lice for several months and that treatments were being applied. “But my professional opinion is that this was an extended lice case where nothing was being done to combat it. The hairdresser said she could tell that the girlaposs hair had not been brushed in months and had tangled into a deep dreadlock matting that would have been impossible to treat with lice solution. This is sadly the result of child neglect,” she continued. It takes a very long time for lice to reach the point of severe infestation. It takes an even longer amount of time for hair to go that matted. In the video, which Rachel shared with her three million followers, the hairdresser films the child’s hair which can be seen crawling with lice. She said: “This poor child has obviously had lice for a very long time. Her hair has not been brushed in ages and has turned into one big ball of lice and knots, which meant that I called Child Protective Services right away.” Showing a clip of her usual method used on a previous client, Rachel wets the hair and applies a conditioning treatment before combing through the hair. Using glass, she “pops” the lice, pressing down to kill them. Sadly, this was not an option for the child and would have been too painful due to the matted condition of her hair. “In usual cases, it’s just a matter of combing through the hair section by section and popping the lice but I didn’t want to put a metal comb anywhere near this poor baby’s hair, Rachel said. “You can even see the lice were drinking blood out of her forehead. This broke my heart to see but I’m really glad she’s okay now.” The post went viral, racking up . million likes and being viewed  million times. One person commented: “Watching her wipe her tears made me have to do the same thing. I’m so sad for her but glad to hear she is safe.” Another user said: “I’m so so thankful that you stood up for her and protected her. Some users commented there was “no excuse” for the girl’s condition, while other people said their heads were itchy after watching the footage. After removing the lice infestation, Rachel updated her followers to explain the child had been picked up by CPS and was taken to hospital. “Although it was not the finished result anyone was hoping for, I know she feels a whole lot better with a fresh start so her scalp can start to heal, she said. Filming the hair for a follow-up post, Rachel explained the child’s hair had been detaching from the scalp. She says: “This left no space for the lice to move anywhere so they had to go on her hands and her neck to drink blood out of her body like that.” “Also there was a smell that leads me to believe there was some kind of mould in the matting here. “It’s very rare I see cases like this but it always breaks my heart.” Rachel also added that the stigma surrounding head lice is a big contributing factor to the spread of lice, as well as a “lack of education” and “embarrassment”. title: i resent mum not switching
story: I resent my mum for not switching me back after baby mix up at hospitalRobin said he would not wish the ordeal on his “worst enemy” after a nurse handed him to the wrong mother by mistake at a hospital in Johannesburg, South AfricaRobin now says he understands why Megs and Sandy chose not to swap the pair back Image:  minutes, Nine nowByLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A man who was swapped at birth in South Africa admitted he resents his mum for not switching him back because he grew up poor while the other child was rich. Robin and Gavin were accidentally given to the wrong mothers by a nurse at Nigel Hospital in Johannesburg where they were the only two babies born on that day in February .This meant Robin was raised by single mum Sandy Dawkins who was struggling to get by on the outskirts of Johannesburg while Gavin grew up with wealthier parent Megs Clinton Parker in Pietermaritzburg. The mistaken was not uncovered until two years later when a disagreement over Gavinaposs rightful father led to a DNA test revealing that Megs was not his birth mother.  Hospital records further confirmed that Robin was Megsapos biological son who was growing up with Sandy as his mother. When faced with swapping their birth sons back, Megs and Sandy chose to keep the children they had raised since birth. Speaking nearer the time, one of the parents told  Minutes Australia: You canapost reject a child that youaposve been so close to for two years. Initially I think you protect the one youaposve got. The first few days are shock, then the curiosity comes. Whereaposs my baby   The boys grew up km apart in very dferent environments and referred to each other as brothers. But Robin has since admitted that he wishes his biological mother fought to switch him back. Speaking at age , he said he had dficulty accepting the situation and misses his mother Megs awfully a lot who he speaks to daily on the phone.  He told how le with Sandy was not easy and that he resented Gavin who does get things easy. If Iaposve ever wanted something, Iaposve had to work towards it. I’ve never just had it come towards me, he added. At the time, Gavin described being “happy” with the le he was accidentally given and that he did not feel sorry for Robin. He said: “Saying I thank my lucky stars every day would be wrong but at the same time I was given a le which I’ve now lived and I’m still living and I don’t regret anything.  The boysapos mothers embraced one another like sisters after discovering the mistake in  but chose not to swap the boys back. But Megs missed her biological son and encouraged him to move halfway across the country to her home with Gavin in , leaving Sandy without a child. Speaking at the time, Sandy said: “I just want to know she’s really happy with what she’s achieved. “I mean she’s ruined people’s lives, there’s just no other way to look at it… she’s ruined mine for starters.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Single mumSouth AfricaParenting" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. survives by eating roadkill has puzzled scientists who confirm he is in good health.Amou Jaji claims to have not bathed for decades as he believed it would cause him bad luck and eventually kill him.The elderly manaposs diet is said to consist of mainly raw roadkill including creatures such as porcupines, and he drinks water straight from puddles in the street. The Daily Star says his unusual lestyle choices have made it it dficult to make friends or find a girlfriend.And one of his favourite past-times is smoking a pipe filled with animal manure which has left him more isolated. But he has impressed researchers who say he is perfectly healthy.Have your say on Amouaposs story in the comment section Villagers in Iran have been so impressed by his dedication to his unconventional lestyle, they built him a small shack as an alternative to his usual hole in the ground.Medics who visited the shack in the village of Dejgah, Iran carried out several tests and said that despite his lestyle, Jaji is surprisingly healthy and has no serious diseases or bacteria. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.A relatively dry year,  had a total precipitation of ,. mm , eight millimetres shy of the -year average but a more impressive .mmbelow the -year norm.Eight months of the year had precipitation below the long-term average but February, August and October saw signicantly more rain than would normally be expected.Worth noting is that five of the top dozen wettest years on record have occurred in the last decade. Depending on your outlook,  had  days without measurable rain or  days with it.July  was the driest on record, with just  mm of precipitation recorded and despite having Benmore Garden#s wettest day ever in February  , the whole month’s rainfall did not compete with the same period in .The highest temperature of .°C was observed on July  during an extended settled period of warm and dry weather. January saw the coldest air temperature of the year with -.°C on January .Air frosts were down across the year. In November, for example, there were two occurrences compared to an average six, and in December there were seven as opposed to nine, which is the expected seasonal norm.January, though, had six more days with air frost than expected compared to the -year norm.There were  occurrences of ground frost throughout the year which is as expected in comparison with trends for the last  years, with the first ground frost of the autumn arriving on September  there was a longer than average ground frost-free period of  days.TemperaturesHighest maximum air temperature: .ºC on July FrostAir frost on:  daysPrecipitationTotal rainfall for year: ,.mm Other phenomenaGale on:  One day # this refers to full gale conditions and does not include sporadic gusts or overnight events where wind speeds cannot be veried by observation.

title: westruther-council-planning-chiefs-overruled-house-bid
story: ELECTED officials have overruled the council’s planning officers after backing a proposal near a Borders village due to “exceptional circumstances”.The applicant, Donald McLeod, sought planning permission in principle to build a house close to Westruther with “specialist facilities” to accommodate the family’s specic health and welfare needs.Scottish Borders Councilroad officials objected to the development due it being unsafe for pedestrians to walk between the village and the proposed site.But members of the local authority’s planning and building standards committee supported the applicant at a meeting on Monday , with Mid Berwickshire councillor Donald Moffat describing it as “the right thing to do”.Council leader Mark Rowley, of the Conservatives, took the “very rare” step of calling in the application.Speaking at the meeting he said: “I initiated the call in after becoming aware of the McLeod family’s very unique challenges and the equally unique opportunity to mitigate them here on this site thanks to the generous support of neighbours.”The leader, who is also a Mid Berwickshire councillor, added that the house would “keep the family at the heart of their community”.According to Barry Fotheringham, SBC principal planning officer, the community council and seven healthcare professionals gave their support to the house proposal.But SBC planning officials recommended that the application should be refused due to pedestrian safety concerns, as well as the potential for “a signicant adverse impact upon the composition and quality of the landscape character”.A report published ahead of the meeting states: “Whilst acknowledging the applicant’s personal circumstances, there are no material planning considerations that would support the erection of a dwelling in this particular location, and there are no known extenuating circumstances or other material considerations, which indicate support for this development as an exception from the Local Development Plan. Regrettably, the principle of development is not considered acceptable in this location.”.removeIt adds: “The planning authority understands the applicant’s circumstances and need to find alternative, fit for purpose family accommodation that meets their very specic needs. Unfortunately, their very specic personal circumstances are not material to the assessment of this application and cannot be taken into account when determining the acceptability, or otherwise, of the proposed development.”However, at the meeting Mr Moffat, of the SNP, moved a formal proposal to approve the plans which was seconded by Hawick representative Clair Ramage.He said: “The family want to stay in the community where they have got a support mechanism. It’s important in cementing a local community together and stopping rural depopulation.“These are definitely exceptional circumstances. In pure planning terms I’ve heard what has been said and normally you wouldn’t take certain things into consideration.“I don’t often disagree with the planning officers [but] I would quite happily approve this in principle because it’s the right thing to do.”

title: scott-praises-efforts-departing-boss-hastings
story: MARTIN ‘Jimmy’ Scott says he is "honoured and excited" to take over as manager of Gala Fairydean Rovers.The former Ross County and Hibs player joined Rovers last summer as assistant to Neil Hastings, who has left the club for a full-time position.Scott has appointed former Aberdeen player Steven Craig as his number two and he will join the club this week.Speaking following his appointment the new gaffer said: “I’m honoured and excited to be appointed manager of the club and I am really looking forward to getting started this week.“It will be a smooth transition for me, and this is credit to the players, staff and everyone who’s involved in the operation of the club.“I’ve worked very closely with Neil over the last six months and ultimately the philosophy will remain the same in how we want to approach the game although I will always keep putting the demands on the players to improve on the good work already done.“I have added Steven Craig to assist with first team operations and to attract someone of Stevie’s pedigree shows what a fantastic club we have here and he’s very excited to start working with myself, staff and the squad.“On a personal note, I’m absolutely delighted for Neil moving to a full-time position in football. He certainly deserves that opportunity and I have no doubt he will be a huge success.“Anyone associated with the club would agree this day would eventually arrive as he has a big future in coaching and management, and he certainly leaves Gala with everyone’s best wishes.”Neil Hastings took charge of the club back in  and made an immediate impact with his professionalism, ambition and passion.He led the Fairydean Rovers to their highest league finish last season.

title: minister-fled-extremism-joins-peeblesshire-churches
story: A MINISTER who fled extremism in Pakistan has been inducted at Peebles Parish Church.Reverend Aftab Gohar moved to the town earlier this month after joining from Abbotsgrange in Grangemouth.Originally from Peshawar in Pakistan, the -year-old, his we Samina and their two sons came to Scotland in  to escape the threat of terrorism.But in  the Gohar family suffered a tragedy when Aftabs -year-old mother, his niece, nephew and two uncles were killed when extremists targeted his home church in Peshawar.The attack was later claimed by two militant groups linked to the Taliban.At the time, Rev Gohar told the BBC that he forgave the suicide attackers, saying: "It is wrong what these people did but I forgive them".When the incident happened, Aftab was the minister at Abbotsgrange Parish Church.But after more than a decade in the Forth Valley, he says it is time for a change.He told us: "After  years we wanted to move on and Peebles, with all its scenery and beauty, invited us to come here."We visited this town three or four times."Once on our wedding anniversary we came to Peebles and stayed here."We like the scenery and the town as a whole."Rev. Gohar held his first services in Peebles and Stobo on January  and his first in Eddleston on January .And he says parishioners have been more than welcoming."Ive really enjoyed meeting people in all three churches," he added.As part of his ministry Rev. Gohar wants to engage with the Peeblesshire community.He said: "I will try to reach out to the community and serve the community through other ministries, I served in Rotary [before] which is a non-church thing but I love to help the community in dferent ways."My style of ministry is pastoral, so I would love to reach out to people."I will not just rely on those people who come to the church on Sunday morning, I will try to reach out to members who are unable to come to church for a iety of reasons..remove"My hopes are that these three churches will flourish and work together for the kingdom of God."
